definition: to speak in a loud distinct voice so as to be heard at a distance : shout
examples: call for help

definition: to make a request or demand
examples: call for an investigation

definition: to utter a characteristic note or cry
to speak to or attempt to reach someone by means of a call (see call entry 2 sense 8)
examples: just called to say hello
I call once a week to talk to my parents.
Several weeks later our son's family called to FaceTime with us.
— Daily Reporter (Greenfield, IN)
She called up and asked if we wanted to come over for dinner.

definition: to make a demand in card games (as for a particular card or for a show of hands)
to give the calls for a square dance
to make a brief visit
examples: called to pay his respects
called on a friend

definition: to utter in a loud distinct voice, to announce or read loudly or authoritatively, to announce the play-by-play of (a sports event, such as a football game)
examples: call out a number
call the roll
call off a row of figures

definition: to command or request to come or be present, to cause to come : bring
examples: was called to testify
calls to mind an old saying

definition: to summon to a particular activity, employment, or office
examples: was called to active duty
was called to the bar of justice

definition: to invite or command to meet : convoke
examples: call a meeting

definition: to rouse from sleep or summon to get up
to give the order for : bring into action, to manage by giving the signals or orders
examples: call a strike against the company
call a pitchout
that catcher calls a good game

definition: to make a demand in bridge for (a card or suit), to require (a player) to show the hand in poker by making an equal bet, to challenge to make good on a statement, to charge with or censure for an offense
examples: deserves to be called on that

definition: to attract (game) by imitating the characteristic cry
to halt (something, such as a baseball game) because of unsuitable conditions
to rule on the status of (a pitched ball, a player's action, etc.)
examples: call balls and strikes
call a base runner safe

definition: to give the calls for (a square dance)
to demand payment of especially by formal notice, to demand presentation of (something, such as a bond or option) for redemption
examples: call a loan
The bonds could be called 10 years after issue.

definition: to speak to or attempt to reach (someone) by means of a call (see call entry 2 sense 8), to generate signals for (a telephone number) in order to reach the party to whom the number is assigned, to make a signal to in order to transmit a message
examples: call the doctor to make an appointment
I try to call my parents at least once a week.
He arranged for his wife, Stacey, to call him via Skype online from Kylee's fourth-grade classroom on Monday morning—a complete surprise to his daughter.
— Elaine Allenemrich
Call me up when you get back from your vacation.
call 911
call the flagship

definition: to speak of or address by a specified name : give a name to
examples: call her Kitty

definition: to regard or characterize as of a certain kind : consider, to estimate or consider for purposes of an estimate or for convenience
examples: can hardly be called generous
call it an even dollar

definition: to describe correctly in advance of or without knowledge of the event : predict, to name or specify in advance
examples: He called the upward trend of the stock market in February.
call the toss of a coin

definition: to temporarily transfer control of computer processing to (something, such as a subroutine or procedure)
to call a thing by its right name however coarse
to speak frankly
examples: Why don't you just call a spade a spade and say that he is a liar?

definition: to call (as at one's house) to get
examples: I'll call for you after dinner

definition: to require as necessary or appropriate
examples: the job calls for typing skills
the design calls for three windows

definition: elicit, evoke
examples: these events call forth great emotions

definition: to cast doubt upon
examples: a report calling into question the drug's effectiveness

definition: to stop for the remainder of the day or for the present whatever one has been doing
examples: worked another couple of hours and then called it a day

definition: to call it a day : quit
to address or speak of a person or thing contemptuously or offensively
to call upon
examples: Is there anyone you can call on in an emergency?

definition: to elicit a response from (someone, such as a student)
examples: the teacher called on her first

definition: to directly criticize (someone) for (something, such as bad behavior)
examples: … offering ample ammunition to anyone wanting to call her on her fascination with all things violent and degrading.
— Michael Upchurch

definition: to challenge in order to expose an empty pretense or threat
examples: I called his bluff just to see if he really meant what he said.
— Brandy Rankins

definition: to be in charge or control : determine the policy or procedure
examples: The secretary called the shots all through the meeting.

definition: to call the shots
to ask for or grant a time-out
to hold responsible : reprimand
examples: He was called to account by his boss for making the error.

definition: require, oblige
examples: may be called upon to do several jobs

definition: to make a demand on : depend on
examples: universities are called upon to produce trained professionals

definition: an act of calling with the voice : shout
examples: a call for help

definition: an imitation of the cry of a bird or other animal made to attract it
an instrument used for calling
examples: a duck call

definition: the cry of an animal (such as a bird)
a request or command to come or assemble
a summons or signal on a drum, bugle, or pipe
admission to the bar as a barrister
an invitation to become the minister of a church or to accept a professional appointment
a divine vocation or strong inner prompting to a particular course of action
a summoning of actors to rehearsal
examples: the call is for 11 o'clock

definition: the attraction or appeal of a particular activity, condition, or place
examples: the call of the wild

definition: an order specifying the number of men to be inducted into the armed services during a specified period
the selection of a play in football
examples: the quarterback's call in the huddle

definition: demand, claim
examples: The aircraft industry continues to have first call on aluminum production.
— Americana Annual

definition: need, justification
examples: there's no call for such behavior

definition: a demand for payment of money
an option to buy a specified amount of a security (such as stock) or commodity (such as wheat) at a fixed price at or within a specified time — compare put sense 2
an instance of asking for something : request
examples: many calls for Christmas stories

definition: roll call
a short usually formal visit
examples: pay a call on a neighbor

definition: the name or thing called
examples: the call was heads

definition: the act of calling in a card game
the act of speaking to or attempting to reach someone by telephone or by a similar online communication service
examples: a telephone call
a video call
made a call to the mayor
In a time before keeping in touch was an internet call away, I'd have to say goodbye forever to bedrooms, to classrooms, to friends.
— Soniah Kamal
Soon after news of Bazemore's return broke, Curry shared a screenshot on Instagram of the two friends on a FaceTime call. Both were smiling, no longer thinking of what-ifs.
— Wes Goldberg

definition: a direction or a succession of directions for a square dance rhythmically called to the dancers
a decision or ruling made by an official of a sports contest, decision sense 1
examples: a tough call to make

definition: a temporary transfer of control of computer processing to a particular set of instructions (such as a subroutine or procedure)
available for use : at the service of
examples: thousands of men at his call

definition: ready to respond to a summons or command
examples: a doctor on call

definition: subject to demand for payment or return without previous notice
examples: money lent at call

definition: within hearing or reach of a summons : subject to summons
